title.narrative: WWF Protected Areas for Nature and People (PA4NP) Regional Västra Balkan
WWF Protected Areas for Nature and People (PA4NP) Regional Western Balkans

description.narrative: Sida initiated a dialogue with WWF to explore how WWF Sweden and WWF Adria could contribute to the Results strategy for Sweden´s reform cooperation with Eastern Europe, the Western Balkans and Turkey 2014-2020 with a specific focus on biodiversity and civil society in the Western Balkans. WWF Sweden and WWF Adria came back with a proposal: The Protected Areas for Nature and People (PA4NP). The programme was launched in September 2015 with the ultimate objective phrased “Sustainable use of natural capital in Western Balkans forms a base for social and economic development and is safeguarded through enhanced environmental responsibility among general public, governments, CSOs and business sector”. The theory of change underpinning the programme aimed to strengthen the engagement of local communities in the management of Protected Areas (PAs) and build the constituency for influencing and monitoring national policies for the environment in eight Western Balkans (WB) countries.

Världsnaturfonden WWF har ansökt om totalt 36 MSEK för att genomföra programmet "Protected Areas for Nature and People". Totalkostnaden för insatsen är 38,6 MSEK och samfinansieras med MAVA foundation. Programmet ska genomföras under en fyraårsperiod mellan 2015-2019. Insatsen utgör en fortsättning samt vidareutveckling av ett regionalt samarbete mellan WWF och Norge/MAVA foundation.
Det långsiktiga målet med insatsen är ett hållbart användande av naturresurser som bas för social och ekonomisk utveckling i länderna på Västra Balkan detta ska samtidigt säkerställas genom ökad miljöansvar hos allmänhet, myndigheter, enskilda organisationer samt företag.
Västra Balkan är en av europas rikaste områden vad gäller biodiversitet och orörda naturområden både vad gäller land och hav. Regionens naturområden och naturresurser är samtidigt under stora hot från illegal skogsavverkning, jakt och fiske samt olika infrastrukturinvesteringar och bostadsbyggande. I jämförelse med internationella mål så är arealen av skyddade naturområden i länderna på Västra Balkan låg samt att naturresursförvaltning och finansiering därav har låg prioritet.
Som ett resultat i WWFs tidigare regionala samarbete framtogs ett regionalt avtal "Big Win" mellan de 8 länderna på Västra Balkan där man överenskommit om både regionala samt nationella mål för att förbättra naturskyddet. Big Win målen inkluderar överenskommelse mellan länderna att arbeta för ett uppfyllande av internationella direktiv inkl EU direktiven vad gäller naturskydd. EU perspektivet ses som en möjlighet/medel inom en annars lågprioriterad sektor att få till en förändring av naturskyddet. Det finns ett flertal direktiv inom naturskyddet som måste uppfyllas vid en EU-anpassning, det gäller även EU nätverket av naturskyddsområden inom EU - det sk Natura 2000. Syftet med Natura 2000 är att bidra till bevarandet av den biologiska mångfalden inom EU och områden utses baserat på direktiven. Folkligt deltagande är ett medel för ett hållbart genomförande av EU-direktiven. De största svagheterna med Natura 2000 områden inom EU är bristen på politisk vilja hos lokala och nationella myndigheter i kombination med dålig kunskap om olika intressentgrupper som bor eller verkar i naturskyddsområdena.
Insatsen ska främja ökad ekonomisk, social och ekologisk hållbar förvaltning av naturresurser detta ska bland annat ske genom att öka parkförvaltningarnas roll i att utveckla lokalsamhällena som finns i parkerna med omnejd. Insatsen kommer tex att utveckla nya alternativa lösningar för att öka intäkter för parkerna men även inkomsterna för lokalsamhällen och företag. Programmet avser också att öka dialogen mellan naturparker/lokalsamhällen och nationella myndigheter och därigenom påverkan på nationella policies inom miljöområdet. Det ingår också i insatsen att vidareförmedla och lära ut goda erfarenheter från "pilotparkerna" i insatsen till parker/skyddade naturområden inom hela regionen. Den regionala aspekten är viktig i insatsen och bidrar förutom till en enhetlig utveckling av naturresursförvaltning i länderna på Västra Balkan även till försoning. Tidigare regionala insatser WWF haft i Västra Balkan har just visat på att sakfrågor kring naturskydd är ett bra område att ha dialog och samarbete om tex gemensamma naturresurser.

Världsnaturfonden WWF has applied to Sida of 36 million SEK from Sida to carry out a regional Program "Protected Areas for nature and people" during the period 2015-2019.
Distribution: No country allocations in advance.
The objective of the contribution is to achieve sustainable use of natural capital in 8 countries of the Western Balkans forming a basis for social and economic development and is safeguarded through enhanced environmental responsibility among the general public, governments and the business sector.The natural capital of the Western Balkan countries is a key asset of the region and the accession process to EU offers extensive opportunities for development and changes in policy of individual countries in all sectors including nature conservation.
The Program will help the management and administration bodies for the protected areas (PAs) to increase their role in local social and economic development and their engagement with local constituents throughout the region. The program also aims to increase WWF and partners engagement with decision-makers and key-influencers of protected area policies (incl EU Nature Directives at national level). WWF will also have field projects in at least five PAs where they will test and demonstrate ways in which PAs can improve their delivery of social and economic benefits. The field sites are "learning platforms" and lessons generated will be captured and distributed throughout the region.

participating-org.narrative: WWF/World Wide Fund for Nature, Sweden
WWF/World Wide Fund for Nature, Sweden

tag.narrative: 15.1 - By 2020, ensure the conservation, restoration and sustainable use of terrestrial and inland freshwater ecosystems and their services, in particular forests, wetlands, mountains and drylands, in line with obligations under international agreements.

15.1 - Till 2020 bevara, återställa och hållbart använda ekosystem på land och i sötvatten och deras ekosystemtjänster, särskilt skogar, våtmarker, berg och torra områden, i enlighet med de skyldigheter som anges i internationella överenskommelser.
15.5 - Take urgent and significant action to reduce the degradation of natural habitats, halt the loss of biodiversity and, by 2020, protect and prevent the extinction of threatened species.

15.5 - Vidta omedelbara och betydande åtgärder för att minska förstörelsen av naturliga livsmiljöer, hejda förlusten av biologisk mångfald och senast 2020 skydda och förebygga utrotning av hotade arter.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Sida assesses that the key achievements are connected to the increase capacity of civil society and local populations in the management of Protected Areas in the Western Balkans. Project specific results include: Mutual benefits of cooperation between PAs and local communities, which were demonstrated through the creation of 52 distinct social benefits that PAs offers to visitors or local communities. These benefits include sustainable tourism packages (wildlife watching), nature trails, national and regional educational programs, as well as stakeholder councils for participatory management of PAs. Strengthened civil society, that was enabled through capacity building for participation and engagement with duty-bearers on specific issues (e.g. Coalition 27 participation), including strengthening the capacities of local initiatives to organize and stand for their rights (e.g. support to the Women of Krušcica initiative). Increased recognition, by more than half of all engaged environmental duty-bearers, of the benefits of cooperation with CSOs. This is visible, inter alia, by the inclusion of CSOs in preparation of country reports for CBD, and participation in integrative planning of large carnivore management plans. Integrated Human rights-based approach (HRBA) and gender mainstreaming in the design and implementation of all programme activities, thus also building awareness and capacities of the programme stakeholders (duty-bearers and rights-holders alike) on these two principles. Development of new tools to support assessment of the level of interaction between PAs and local communities (i.e. Community Involvement Assessment methodology) and promotion of good practice of PA/local community cooperation for replication and upscaling (i.e. natureforpeople.org). - The programme also generated three key unforeseen positive impacts: large interest of schools and kindergartens for WWF Nature Academy, connections between PAs in the regions without intentional facilitation of WWF Adria, integration of HRBA in the remaining WWF Adria activities. - While there is still a way to go to achieve the Ultimate Outcome, the programme has remained relevant for the region’s current issues of highest priorities regarding socio-economic context of PAs and governance and the results of the PA4NP has therefore successfully laid the necessary foundation for transformational change of the magnitude needed to ensure sustainable use of natural capital in the WB countries. - The project has contributed to strengthening cooperation between local communities and local authorities regarding nature protected areas and contributed to increased knowledge about ecotourism. - The project contributed to the founding of Park Dinarides: a regional network of authorities that manage nature protected areas. The network now brings together 95 protected areas in eight countries: Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Croatia, Kosovo, Northern Macedonia, Slovenia and Serbia. - Data and information on nature-protected areas have been collected and followed up in seven pilot studies in the Western Balkans region. Through the Grant Program for Protected Areas, civil society organizations in the region have received support for different local projects and strengthened the influence of local people in management of Protected Areas. - WWF Nature Academy has conducted trainings for teachers and students focusing on biodiversity. 14 environmental organizations in the region have been supported to strengthen the implementation of action plans for protected areas. - The project has supported Bear Watching projects in the Tara National Park in Serbia that in turn have led to increased income opportunities for the local population and strengthened people's sense of ownership in the conservation of the bears. - In Bosnia and Herzegovina, WWF Adria cooperated with the women's rights initiative "EkoBistro" in the village of Krušcica, which, after protests, managed to stop the construction of two hydroelectric plants that would have affected their access to water and the opportunity to grow food.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
